sections.text:
This feature adds an “issue clustering v2” post-processing step that automatically identifies clusters that are likely too broad to be useful for triage. After the initial clustering run, we’ll compute cohesion/dispersion signals (e.g., intra-cluster similarity, cluster size thresholds, topic entropy) to flag clusters where themes are mixed or volume is too high, which today forces manual re-reading and ad hoc splitting.

For any flagged cluster, the job will generate candidate split suggestions into proposed child clusters. Each suggestion will be accompanied by the metrics that triggered the flag and representative examples—such as the top conversations/issues per proposed child cluster—so a reviewer can quickly validate whether the split is sensible without re-running clustering or rebuilding context.

We’ll persist these split suggestions as first-class records and expose them through an internal API so they can be displayed in the triage UI. This makes the outputs durable (auditable over time, comparable across runs) and creates a clear workflow bridge from “broad cluster detected” → “review suggested splits” → “promote to actionable clusters” → “link to downstream engineering work.”

The expected impact is faster, higher-quality triage with less manual cluster grooming and fewer “miscellaneous” buckets that hide priority signals. It should also improve downstream execution by producing more specific, well-scoped problem areas that map cleanly to owners, initiatives, and tickets, while preserving transparency via stored metrics and examples for reviewer trust.
